Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Models, Representations, and Dimensionality Reduction Techniques for Structured Data Sets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT:

A significant byproduct of the modern Information Age has been an explosion in the sheer quantity of data demanded from sensing systems. This project focuses on developing effective new frameworks for data acquisition, processing, and understanding that will help meet the technological challenges posed by this ever growing demand for information. Possible areas of impact include, but are not limited to: social choice theory, recommendation engines, sensor networks, computer vision, LIDAR, machine learning, medical imaging, drug discovery, and neuroscience. Integrated with the research in this project are the educational goals to inspire and educate students by creating and disseminating new curricular and K-12 outreach materials that focus both on the challenges of high-dimensional data processing and on the principles behind the dimensionality reduction techniques for alleviating them.

The research in this project draws from the concepts of sparsity and geometry in pursuing theoretically sound, integrated models and representations for broad classes of natural data. Of particular interest are (i) pairwise comparison matrices, which arise in a number of applications including recommendation engines, economic exchanges, elections, and psychology but are inadequately captured by low-rank models, and (ii) point clouds, which arise in signal and image databases and sensor networks but for which current models fail to properly capture intra- and inter-signal structures. In order to help mitigate the challenges in collecting and storing high-dimensional data sets (including those above), this project is developing principled techniques for recovering matrix-structured data sets from partial information that exploit far richer models than conventional low-rank recovery techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A significant byproduct of the modern Information Age has been an explosion in the sheer quantity of data demanded from sensing systems. To help meet the technological challenges posed by this ever growing demand for information, this project aimed to address several basic research challenges by identifying and establishing (1) new mathematical models and representations for high-dimensional data sets that combine the concepts of sparsity and geometry in order to better capture the structure underlying broad classes of data collections and to permit new and more efficient techniques for dimensionality reduction of these collections, and (2) new theory and methods for recovering structured data sets from partial information that exploit sparse and geometric models for signals and matrices.

Signals and data sets come in many forms, and this project considered and developed a variety of models and representations appropriate for different scenarios. Sparsity is one commonly used model for signals. In addition to conventional sparse models, this project considered extensions of sparsity in redundant dictionaries, as well as a generalization of the concept of sparsity to low-dimensional manifold models which can more efficiently capture the structure of certain parameterized signal families. Meanwhile, low-rank structure is a commonly used model for matrix-structured data sets or multi-signal collections (such as arise in a sensor network). In addition to conventional low-rank models, this project considered the incorporation of side information into low-rank models, manifold models for signal collections, joint sparsity among image ensembles, second moment matrices in scientific computing, and structured low-rank matrices that arise in certain inverse problems involving non-stationary blind super-resolution. To mention one specific example, pairwise comparison matrices arise in a number of applications including recommendation engines, economic exchanges, elections, and psychology. We proposed a new structured, low-rank model for pairwise comparison matrices that accommodates nontransitive pairwise comparisons.

This project also considered techniques for efficiently reducing the dimensionality of such structured signals and data sets, and for recovering these signals and data sets when only partial information is available. One focus area was related to structural health monitoring, where our interest was in data sets that are acquired when monitoring the health of a structure, such as a building or a bridge, from wireless vibration sensors spread across the structure. In order to manage the quantity of data generated in such a scenario, we considered various strategies for the sensors to randomly subsample or compress their data sets, and we characterized the ability of different algorithms to recover the structure’s modal parameters (mode shapes and frequencies) from the compressed data set. In general, research in structural health monitoring could improve the ability to detect damage in our nation's aging infrastructure, and reduce the cost of monitoring this infrastructure. To give some more general representative examples of the project outcomes, we also identified conditions under which the information in manifold-modeled signals is preserved when the signals are randomly compressed; we proposed a technique for estimating matrix properties from compressed measurements; we developed an algorithm for recovering pairwise comparison matrices when only a fraction of their entries have been observed; we developed an estimator for second moment matrices that relies only on random point samples of a function, rather than knowledge of its gradients; we developed an algorithm using atomic norm minimization for parameter estimation of complex exponentials from their modulations with unknown waveforms, thus allowing for nonstationary blind super-resolution; and we studied the nonconvex geometry of certain matrix optimization problems that arise in machine learning.

This project also aimed to inspire and educate students by creating and disseminating new curricular materials at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels. A major goal was to help address a vital national need by inspiring female and underrepresented minority students to pursue education and careers in STEM subject areas. In this project, lessons and activities related to digital cameras and image compression, signal filtering, sampling and aliasing, movie recommendation systems, Google PageRank, and signal and video enhancement were presented by the PI and/or students at local summer camps and after school programs. One lesson and one activity were also published in the TeachEngineering Digital Library, a peer-reviewed online repository where educational materials are made freely available to K-12 teachers. All of this began an ongoing outreach effort in the PI’s group that has continued past the end of this project.

This project has directly supported the training and education of several Graduate Research Assistants, most of whom were also involved in creating and presenting K-12 outreach materials. In addition, students in a senior-level Digital Signal Processing class helped create prototype lessons/activities. Three undergraduate students also participated in the research and/or K-12 outreach components of this project under the PI’s supervision. Finally, the PI developed and refined a graduate-level class on Sparse Signal Processing that incorporated elements of signal modeling and dimensionality reduction.
